thread.section_title: Finance | Business and Finance News | News.com.au
thread.title: Western Sydney to heat up as rest of property market cools
thread.title_full: Western Sydney to heat up as rest of property market cools

author: Aidan Devine
title: Western Sydney to heat up as rest of property market cools
text:
WESTERN Sydney home values will continue growing this spring as the rest of the city’s housing market cools.
Sydney’s median house price is forecast to grow another 6 to 7 per cent this financial year, down from almost 18 per cent over the year to June, but growth will occur mostly in affordable western areas, according to BIS Shrapnel.
Managing director Rob Mellor said prices, particularly in the inner city, have reached an affordability ceiling which has made further increases highly unlikely.
Cheaper suburbs in the west and other city pockets, meanwhile, still have room for further price growth, Mr Mellor said.
Core Logic RP Data figures show price growth is already slowing across the Harbour City as a whole.
6 Renshaw Ave, Auburn is one of the more than 700 homes going to auction today. Source: Supplied
Sydney’s median price grew at just 1.1 per cent over August, substantially slower than the 5 per cent increase over July, and weekly auction clearance rates have fallen from autumn highs of 87 per cent to roughly 77 per cent. 28 Bass Dr, Baulkham Hills also goes to auction today. Source: Supplied
Spring has also brought an unusually high spike in listings, which promises to ease pressure off of house hunters — more than 700 homes go to auction today, with even higher volumes expected later in the month. But Real Estate Institute of NSW president Malcolm Gunning said it may take a while for the softening conditions to impact Western Sydney.
“Price growth looks to have maxed out in the inner city, but Western Sydney is probably about six months behind,” he said.
Four bedroom home 40 Driscoll St is one of three homes in Abbotsbury going to auction today. Source: Supplied
Auctioneer Rocky Bartolotto added that demand for Western Sydney homes remains rampant, pointing to a Horsley Park home sold at auction this week for $855,000 above its reserve price as proof of a still booming market. “Western Sydney is doing remarkably well,” he said. “Most people have been priced out of suburbs 15km to 20km from the CBD and it has made the west extremely popular because people know they can buy more with their money.”
Outside of the west, buyers would likely have the upper hand at auctions because of the influx of homes for sale, Mr Bartolotto said.
“Unique and well positioned homes will continue to sell for high prices, but other home sellers may need to revise their expectations down a little.”
Mya Ly is auctioning her Hinchinbrook home at 2B Pegasus Avenue today and said she decided to sell under the hammer on the advice of agent John Hana of Raine and Horne and because she realised competition for sales remains stiff.
“Looking at other sales, every home in the area is selling through auction now,” she said. “It’s rare to be able to negotiate with the seller like you used to.”
Originally published as One region to heat up as property market cools
